G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3 because the subject premises are located in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3 because the subject premises are located in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constitutes an indirect interference proscribed by G.L. c. 186, §14, as recognized in Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), where the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord’s failure to control excessive noise from adjacent tenants within the landlord’s control constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landlord’s failure to control objectionable conditions created by another tenant, where the landlord has the right and ability to control them, can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment and support a constructive eviction. The court rejects any nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction in this context and emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct “in what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done” is controlling, fitting the proposition that inaction can be an indirect interference proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. Although the opinion speaks in terms of common‑law covenant/constructive eviction rather than construing § 14 in detail, it is routinely cited as authority for that statutory principle in Massachusetts.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent… To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord… and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Similarly, in Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), the Court affirmed that a landlord’s unreasonable failure to remedy intolerable disturbances from other tenants constituted an actionable breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case does deal with breach of quiet enjoyment, but the interference here was the landlord’s failure to maintain the premises (repeated flooding from common areas), not disturbances caused by other tenants. The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis focuses on unsanitary physical conditions and flooding attributable to the landlord’s failure to keep the apartment watertight, not on intolerable conduct by neighboring tenants. Thus, Simon v. Solomon supports the broader rule that a landlord’s reckless failure to correct serious, foreseeable interferences with habitability can violate quiet enjoyment, but it does not stand for the specific proposition about disturbances from other tenants.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Winchester v. Stevens, 228 Mass. 426 (19.proposition: See also Winchester v. Stevens, 228 Mass. 426 (1917) (recognizing landlord liability for interference resulting from conditions within his control); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (tenant may recover damages under G.L. c. 186, §14 for interference with beneficial use of the premises); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (landlord strictly liable for violation of §14 regardless of intent).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: See also Winchester v. Stevens, 228 Mass. 426 (1917) (recognizing landlord liability for interference resulting from conditions within his control); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (tenant may recover damages under G.L. c. 186, §14 for interference with beneficial use of the premises); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (landlord strictly liable for violation of §14 regardless of intent).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that the tenant was entitled to declaratory and injunctive relief, damages, and counsel fees under G.L. c. 186, § 14 based on interference with quiet enjoyment arising from the lack of heat. The court rejects any intent requirement and confirms that a tenant may recover civil damages under § 14 for such interference, directly supporting the proposition that a tenant may recover damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for interference with beneficial use of the premises.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “It was claimed that the defendants had violated those portions of G. L. c. 186, § 14…who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish…heat…or…who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises…. On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction…; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: See also Winchester v. Stevens, 228 Mass. 426 (1917) (recognizing landlord liability for interference resulting from conditions within his control); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (tenant may recover damages under G.L. c. 186, §14 for interference with beneficial use of the premises); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (landlord strictly liable for violation of §14 regardless of intent).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Al‑Ziab holds a landlord is strictly liable for violation of G.L. c. 186, §14 regardless of intent. Al‑Ziab holds the opposite: it clarifies that some degree of landlord fault is required under §14 and that strict liability under the lead paint statute does not automatically create §14 liability. The case therefore undercuts, rather than supports, the stated proposition about strict liability under §14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp., 52 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp., 52 Mass. App. Ct. 763 (2001)
Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp., 52 Mass. Ap.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates the rule articulated in Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp., 52 Mass. App. Ct. 763 (2001), confirming that excessive noise originating within a landlord’s property, where remedial power rests with the landlord, can form the basis of a quiet enjoyment claim.
Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp., 52 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp.; it is a criminal case involving violation of a G.L. c. 209A abuse prevention order and concerns stay‑away and no‑contact provisions, not quiet enjoyment or landlord-tenant law. The decision does not discuss excessive noise, landlord control over conditions, or tenant quiet enjoyment claims. Therefore, it cannot support the proposition about noise-based quiet enjoyment liability for landlords.
Foster v. 1000 Realty Corp., 52 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: In this case, the defendant concededly failed to “stay at least fifty yards away from [the protected party]” when he exited the car, walked into the former wife’s apartment complex, and stood within four or five yards of her door. … In the final analysis, violation of a G. L. c. 209A order’s stay away provisions are properly prosecuted as statutory offenses.

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: In Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005), the court reaffirmed that a landlord’s failure to correct disturbances caused by other tenants can result in liability under §14.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss disturbances caused by other tenants or a landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, §14 for failing to correct such disturbances. Its quiet enjoyment analysis is limited to physical defects in the tenant’s own unit and the landlord’s prompt repairs, concluding there was no interference with quiet enjoyment. It neither reaffirms nor addresses the specific principle that failing to remedy disturbances caused by other tenants can create §14 liability.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Numerous decisions—Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); and Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass. 631 (1986)—reinforce tenants’ statutory and contractual right to peaceful possession, free from unreasonable interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes tenants’ rights to use and enjoy their leased premises free from serious interference and treats those rights as both statutory (G.L. c. 186, § 14) and contractual (the covenant of quiet enjoyment in the lease). The Court holds that if the housing authority’s omissions in addressing criminal activity in common areas substantially impair tenants’ ability to use the property, that can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, and it remands for trial on that claim. This directly reinforces a tenant’s right to peaceful possession free from unreasonable interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt:
“The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold…

In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… If the defendant failed to take any action… then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Numerous decisions—Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); and Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass. 631 (1986)—reinforce tenants’ statutory and contractual right to peaceful possession, free from unreasonable interference.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on counterclaims for breach of warranty of habitability, breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and especially the availability and measure of damages under G.L. c. 93A, including for emotional distress. Although a quiet enjoyment claim was pleaded and found in Gonzalez’s favor, the Supreme Judicial Court’s discussion does not substantively analyze or elaborate tenants’ statutory or contractual right to peaceful possession or freedom from unreasonable interference. The case is thus not meaningful authority for the broad proposition about reinforcing tenants’ right to peaceful possession, and is instead about c. 93A remedies and damages measures.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action... the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); ... After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A... We now affirm.

Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass..raw_text: Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass. 631 (1986)
Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass..proposition: Numerous decisions—Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991); and Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass. 631 (1986)—reinforce tenants’ statutory and contractual right to peaceful possession, free from unreasonable interference.
Young v. Boston Housing Auth., 398 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns tenants’ statutory and contractual right to peaceful possession and freedom from unreasonable interference in a housing context. The opinion provided is Commonwealth v. Mayfield, a criminal homicide case dealing with grand jury integrity, evidentiary rulings, and procedural issues, not landlord-tenant law or tenants’ rights. It does not discuss peaceful possession, housing authorities’ obligations to tenants, or any related statutory or contractual rights, so it cannot support the stated proposition.
